docs.text: i have to admit that i disliked this film initially .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it certianly isn't for every taste , and it's sheer torture to sit through if you're in a restless mood .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: that said , if you are in the right mood , it's absolutely incredible .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this was my second favorite movie of 1998 , and would have been a shoo-in for first in almost any other year .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: perhaps the big turn-off for many was this film's unconventionality .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i'd be hard-pressed to compare it to any other film that i've seen - it is very , very artsy , incredibly slow - and amazingly , it works beautifully .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: on my second viewing , i realized that the film follows the three act structure ( i didn't think it had any sort of structure at all when i first saw it ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the first act serves to set up the characters - sort of .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it exists even moreso to set a mood of tension and restlesness , and perhaps even feelings of boredom .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: and then it is shattered by the intense violence of the second ( which encompasses most of the movie ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the majority of the film is one extended battle scene , intercut with brief flashbacks and voice-overs .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the artsier elements do not detract from the action , but add to it - they succeed in briefly letting the viewer peek into the minds of the soldiers , only to be suddenly yanked back into reality when the battle resumes .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the battle scenes are amazing ( second only to " saving private ryan " in my opinion ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: they're brutal , horrifying , and at times beautiful due to the amazing cinematography .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the second act is as immersive , brilliant , and haunting as any film that i have ever seen .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the only problems come during the first and third acts .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: malick takes a little too long to get the film started .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: although the initial scenes - which consist of two soldiers' experiencing a near-eden-like paradise while going awol , and the preperations for battle - are effective and necessary , hints of pretentiousness sink in .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film is just a tad too artsy near the beginning , and a lot of people that disliked the movie probably gave up on it because of this .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the final act is effective at winding the film down , but the problems from the first persist - it's a bit too long , and comes over as pretentious at times .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: that said , there are two sequences ( one where a soldier gets a devastating note from his wife , and another where one of the main characters is killed ) that are nothing short of incredible .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the performances are phenominal all around .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the two standouts are nick nolte and newcomer jim caviezel , both of whom should have been nominated for oscars .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: nolte is riveting and intense as the colonel in charge of the operation .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his character is hard , mean , and somewhat reckless with the lives of his men , and yet nolte somehow manages to evoke sympathy for him .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: caviezel is forever questioning the nature of war , his place in it , and if there's any deeper meaning to the hell that he's going through .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he is absolutely perfect - genuine , sympathetic , sincere , and yet strong when he needs to be .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: although restricted to a relatively small role , sean penn is also very good as the company's pessimistic seargent .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: as to how it stacks up to " saving private ryan " - it was my second favorite movie of 1998 , " ryan " was my first .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's really hard to compare the two - they are so , so different - so i won't , beyond saying that spielberg's film had more of an impact on me .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: however , the two are comparable from the standpoint of quality ( i can easily see why someone would " the thin red line " above " ryan ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i highly recommend both of them , and consider them to be the two best war movies ever made .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: all in all , " the thin red line " is filmmaking of an incredibly high order .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's slight faults are easily offset by the sheer brilliance of what is done right .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's a real shame that it tanked at the box office - films this unconventional , powerful , and thought-provoking don't come along very often .
docs.label: positive
